snippet: For more than a decade, Representative George E. Brown Jr., an old-line liberal Democrat first elected to Congress in 1962, was a top target for Republicans eager to win a seat in California's sprawling ''Inland Empire'' of semi-desert suburbs and...
lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, Representative George E. Brown Jr., an old-line liberal Democrat first elected to Congress in 1962, was a top target for Republicans eager to win a seat in California's sprawling ''Inland Empire'' of semi-desert suburbs and commuter communities. And more than once, Mr. Brown came close to losing, so when the Congressman died in July at 79 after complications from heart surgery, a close race to succeed him seemed all but inevitable. But for the moment, that close race is between two Democrats vying for their party's nomination in a special election on Sept. 21. And the contest, the first Congressional election of the 2000 cycle, says much about the changing demographics of a district where the first McDonald's drive-in opened in the years after World War II. Once a solid blue-collar steel-making center on the path of Route 66, the area became a beachhead of Reagan Republicanism, and in recent years there has been a steady rise in the influence of Hispanic voters, who are expected to exert growing power in California's politics in the coming years.
abstract: Marta Macias Brown, widow of Rep George E Brown Jr, and State Sen Joe Baca lead in race for Democratic nomination for Brown's Congressional seat from California; both are Hispanic in district where newly registered Hispanic voters have swelled Democratic ranks; eight other candidates run in open primary, with top finisher from each party advancing to general election if none gets majority; photo (M)

headline.main: Close Contest for House Seat From California
